title: CTRL0000034628 - Transcribed Interview of Frances Haugen, (December 17, 2021)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held in room 1540A, Longworth House
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
This is a continuation of the transcribed
interview of Frances Haugen, begun on November 22nd, 2021, and conducted by the
House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States
This will be another staff-led interview.
time, members of the select committee may join later and, of course, may choose also to
and I'm an investigative counsel with the select
senior counsel and senior adviser; and
As with last time, I will be asking questions for the staff.
will have an opportunity to review the transcript.
take the lead, ask followup, or ask for clarifications.
Members can join in at any time, to
You are permitted to have an attorney present.
At this time, could counsel please state their name for the record, and, Libby,
could you also please state your name and affiliation.
Hello, this is Andrew Bakaj, and I'm counsel for Ms. Haugen.
I'm the CEO of Whistleblower Aid.
So, Frances, just to make things move smoothly, I'm going to
run through some things that we talked about last time.
is completed before you begin your response, and we will try to wait until your response
is complete before we ask our next question.
The stenographer cannot record nonverbal responses, so -- such as shaking your
head, so it's important that you answer each question with an audible verbal response.
If you need me to repeat a question, let me know.
sure they can capture our statements accurately.
We ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
I also want to let you know, remind you, that it's unlawful to deliberately provide
false information to Congress, even though we're not proceeding under oath today.
So the plan for today is, we have 2 hours, we'll try to get through as much as we
There may be some cleanup from last time, but we're going to try to turn to some
Do you have any questions about that?
question is not clear, please ask for clarification.
If you need a quick break, let us know.
And if the reporters have any clarifying questions, they may interrupt us to make
If you need to talk to your
So could we pull up document 19, and I'm going to mark that as
exhibit F, continuing from last time.
This is also known as -- this is called Carol's Journey
And are you familiar with this document?
So did you provide this document to the committee?
So what is your takeaway from the test user account study?
So this -- this specific study is one of a series of studies, three of which were
done by the same data scientists.
called Strategic Response, that all found the same pattern repeated, which was that you
can begin from relatively centrist interests, you know, center left, center right, and if you
take an account that has no friends, no other interests, and you just click on whatever
Face book gives you -- so you click on the content, you follow the groups, you join the
groups they suggest, that kind of thing -- you end up very rapidly being pushed towards
One was done by another group inside Face book
And that's because the system is designed to try to maximize engagement in the
system, and engagement is defined as, like, likes, comments, reshares, forwarding
something, like a message to someone else, that kind of thing.
And Facebook's internal research has shown repeatedly, and external research,
that it is easier to provoke people to anger than it is to other emotions, and as a result,
you end up having a selective pressure where more and more extreme content is
And can you just talk briefly about groups you may like and pages you may
like and how that -- how a user might interact with them?
So Face book, in order to -- let's imagine a version of Face book that
would be from your family, friends, people you actually know, but Facebook would not be
able to generate as long of sessions; like, people wouldn't look at as much content or as
many ads, and Facebook would make less money.
So the content you would see then would be largely -- it
So Facebook has to figure out how to get you to express interest in pages -- so
that's pages you might know -- and groups.
And right now, the heuristics for deciding
what is a high-quality group are very similar to how content is selected.
have lots and lots of engagement are considered higher quality groups.
The only problem with the strategy is, going back as far as at least 2016, there
have been reports that things like -- I think it was the 2016 disclosure said that it was like
65 percent of people who joined nee-Nazi groups in Germany joined because Facebook
So groups that have more extreme content also, as a general rule, have more
engagement for similar reasons to what I already talked about, and as a result, there is a
bias in terms of which groups Face book will promote to people that come from groups
Do you know if there's a follow-up
study or a different study that might show a similar result about extremist groups in the
United States similar to that nee-Nazi study in Germany?
I know there's a variety of documents that are about how groups'
recommendations are dangerous, like, they're -- I know we have docs that talk about the
idea that, like, Facebook has a lag between when a group is created and when it can
actually assess whether or not that group is a safe group or not.
knew that that was a major security liability, because it allowed, up until, I think pretty
close to the election, if your group got taken down for being a violent group, you could
just go create a new group with the same name and the same admins, and that would be
And you have to go and reaccumulate bad behavior points to
There are other documents that show things, like, because there are bad rate
limits set, so this is, I believe, other documents that you have in the list of enclosures, you
talk -- they talk about how because people could invite so many individuals per day, and
there wasn't good takedown rules for, like, someone might have multiple accounts and
invite, you know, 2,000 people a day from each of those multiple accounts, very rapidly,
you can have thousands and thousands of people invited to a group.
A really important thing for people to be aware of is that you can receive content
from a group for 30 days after you're invited without having actually accepted the
And if you engage in any of that content, it's considered a follow.
So allowing people to mass invite people is dangerous because it creates an
avenue where, let's say, they clickbait you into reacting to something or commenting on
something, now they have successfully gained an avenue to inject content into your news
Let's take -- I have a couple followups.
chronological order from when they came up.
So the fact that if I send someone an invite, they can receive content from that

through the election and through the January 6th period?
We can look through the docs and try to see if it specifically
And you did mention that you think up until close to
the election, there was a lag between --
There was -- I know there was --
So I know that I have a doc from August 2020 that talks about that
I am not sure how -- and I know -- I was in the review meeting where

to be feasible because it would slightly slow down the growth of groups by

And -- but the -- I'm not entirely sure what was done after that.
chance that they may have done something, but I -- I only know that secondhand, like, I

This was a part of a trilogy.
a person who's expressing interest in kind of BJP topics to demonstrate that it pushes you

I think we have that document.
The other one is -- I think it's like Karen --
-- Descent Down the Rabbit Hole, something like that, and it basically is
someone who expresses center left interests and how long does it take them to be shown
The last one, which was not done by the same person but is the exact same

expressing interest in like innocuous topics like healthy eating.
And so, like, it is a -- it is a commonly, like, I think it shows a pattern of behavior in

And you mentioned a review meeting you were in --
-- talking about the groups and the lag.

So there was a meeting called the Civic Integrity Launch Review, and

you were part way through a project, you might go in there.
That finding was reviewed at one of these launch review meetings.
happened -- I think that we had 2 hours' worth of them on Thursdays, once a week.
that was -- that was where I saw that, where I came in contact with that document.

someone waiting, if we can check and see if that's Libby, that would be great.

Facebook would continue to behave in this way, like, going forward.
and downstream MSI are core parts of the ranking, you would continue to see this

measures are, like, putting a brake on a car, right?
So, you know, if you only put the

If you put a bigger brake on, the car

And the break the glass measures act like -- they're intended to be usually kind of
that are -- are potentially in conflict, and the intention is for people to be exposed to less

So in terms of, you know, being able to identify specific parts of the community

So he made a Chrome plug-in that allowed you to mass unfollow, like, the groups

there and be, like, I just don't want to follow all this stuff, but I don't want to have to sit

And Face book threatened to sue

And that's publicly reported, like, you can -- you can find that.
And how was it a threat?
So remember how I said before that, like, the world of Facebook where you

do in the world as currently constructed by Facebook.
things, follow less pages, be members of fewer groups, that directly costs Face book

And so having people follow less

-- on page 15, this document says that in less than a week after opening the

and before that, it had recommended implicit QAnon content.
So do you have -- we're going to turn to another document, but is there anything

I think the fact that so rapidly people are exposed to quite extreme

might be in the Karen one.

That was page 15, less than a week.
So I think a couple things that are interesting are, like,
how concentrated the groups' recommendations are.
about how it took very little time for the groups you should join to become completely
saturated with just political and right-leaning content.
It's like they make a comment
You know, you could imagine doing a design where you intentionally are trying to
integrate people into the broader community, and this shows how it's basically just
optimizing for -- in Al systems, there's a concept known as exploit versus explore.
this is like a generalized concept around all recommender systems.
When you are exploiting, you are trying to optimize as much as possible for what
And explore is like, oh, let's make sure we expose
people to more things, because we might be overfocused in.
like, it sounds like they are overoptimized on exploit over explore.
Low quality -- actually, one more thing you guys should pay attention to is on -- I
don't know which page this is.
It says, several of the pages and
groups shared problematic content and had other markers of low quality, violating
ownership or activity, such as high number of CO deletes -- so that's country operation
deletes -- for admins are in pages and groups with overlapping sets of admins.
So the reason why this is an important phrase, is, if you have overlapping sets of
admins, it means that you have a coordinated movement going on.
problem with QAnon, where you had clusters of accounts that were going and being the
administrators and promoters of groups of pages.
And so what this is saying is that, you know, the algorithm, once you start falling

content is that they've gotten coordinated, inauthentic behavior violations, right, where,
you know, a number of these groups have admins that have already lost other groups for
coordinated, inauthentic behavior, which is a huge problem.
So -- so what basically this doc says is that Facebook knew they were -- they were
pushing people into groups that had these integrity -- known integrity issues.

So, you know, Facebook had lots and lots of options other than making
tactical choices to pull Stop the Steal or the Patriot Party off of Face book, right?
know, they could have chosen lower rate limits for like how many people could be invited
They could have changed things, like, should you receive content from people before you

They could have changed things about how they recommended groups.
But because Facebook chose to run the system really, really hot, by the time Stop
the Steal or the Patriot Party started to become, you know, illicit, real-world violence, like
it induced real-world violence, they didn't have a lot of options other than to remove
One of the things that is more difficult about one of these movements -- and
they're classified as adversarial movements to differentiate between, you know, imagine
a social movement, you know, is full of authentic actors that are using the platform to
organize some kind of movement, versus people who are actively trying to get around
When you have one of these movements that is actionably weaponizing the
platform, you have to have more subtle tools for detecting who is driving the movement,
for being able to see the trends that are, like, the ways that people are recruited or
And what Jeff is referring to here is that they developed technologies, like
information corridors, for being able to understand who was actively pushing ideas
through these networks, who were the ones who were causing the networks to grow.
Because if you can find the, you know, 1 percent of people who are both the recruiters
and the amplifiers and the people who actually generate the ideas, you can, in a tactical
way, remove those people from the system or down-ramp them.
make it so that just those people can't invite people to groups anymore, or they can invite
fewer people to groups per day.
And so I do agree with Jeff's assessment that this is like a targeted intervention,
It's not like just making the system safer.
remove an actor from the platform after the risk to the company becomes too large.

instead of focusing on the aggregate volume of the tail.
